monogr.title: A Digital Dictionary of Shawi Arabic

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the SHAWI teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the share prefix are pointers to audio file residing on the SHAWI network share.
Private URIs using the geo prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a place element in VICAV Geodata list.
Private URIs using the zotid prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a biblStruct element in the TEI export of the VICAV Zotero Group library.
Private URIs using the dict prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a entry in the SHAWI glossary.

spanGrp.span: As for the objection to the marriage, my teacher; we Arabs, the tribes in Ḥarrān, in Urfa we have (a tradtion):
When someone wants his daughter to get married those who ask for the hand of the girl come to him.
Let’s say, we are from the Bani ʕIǧil and someone from the Ğmēle tribe came asking for my daughter’s hand. Let’s say, just for example, we want to give her to them.
First, I would inform my brothers and my cousins telling them, “Brother, I want my daughter to get married with one from the Ğmēle. What do you say?” No one says anything.

We go ahead, let’s say, I have already taken her bride price and we have provided the dowry. After we have provided the dowry we are done. Suddenly, let’s say, one of my relatives from the Bani ʕIǧil, or my brother, or my cousin, Ismāʕīn or Ḥasan, comes and says,
“Brother! Your daughter’s (marriage) is objected. She has no way, there is no way, we will do like this.
We say to him, “Okay brother, but we have taken a bride price from these people, twenty tousand Turkish lira or fifteen thousand.
There is the bride price on which we have agreed on; and these people already had expenses. My brother, (first) go to these people, give them back their expenses, and then you are welcome!”
Then Ḥasan starts to go. Didn’t he object (to the marriage) for the sake of his son? He goes to those people to whom we had given (the girl) first.
“Brother, how much is the bride price that you gave to my brother?” So, he does not take any money from me, but he gives it directly to those he goes to.
The money that has entered my pocket does not go out anymore.
He goes to those people who gave the bride price to us and says, “Brother, how much is the bride price you gave to Ismāʕīn?”
They say, “We gave twenty thousand.” He gives them their twenty thousands.
“Brother, how much are your other expenses, I mean for dowry, oufits, clothes?”
They say, “Our dowry costed around, let’s say, two thousand lira; three thousand lira was our dowry.”

“Bring your dowry, brother, your bundles (of mattresses etc.)!” They bring the dowry to Ḥasan and he gives them the three thousand lira. Then he loads the bundles, the dowry, up and brings it to his house.
Even during the henna night he can object to the marriage. The meaning of al-ᵊḥyār is
I mean it is always (a matter of) kinship; if the relative objects to the marriage of the girl, she is not allowed to go more than one meter away.
Always there is its name; the meaning of al-ᵊḥyār is this, al-ᵊḥyār

It does not only have to be Ḥasan (the speaker’s brother). I mean, let’s say, also a ‘foreigner’; when a stranger comes; my cousins from the village, my maternal and paternal uncles, other relatives I have. Everyone from the Bani ʕIǧil tribe can object the marriage of a girl from the tribe.
Nowadays, it has become way less, not like before. But again, here in the Plain of Ḥarrān the marriage veto exists.
They would let the girl ‘die’; they let her become an old unmarried woman all her life long because of their objection to her marriage.

They will not let her get married (to someone else) saying, “This one is reserved for me, I will not give her away even if I cause to let her die at her home. I will cause to let her die at home, at her mother’s.
As for ‘the cold bread’: when a stranger comes and brings the bride price for my daughter And then there comes the marriage veto.
Let’s say, my daughter’s marriage is objected. To avoid troubles, the foreigner who is not one of our realtives, the one who asks for my daughter’s hand will say,
“Okay brother! There is a marriage veto on you. As long as there is cold bread for us, we do not eat the hot bread. We do not want to burn our mouths. Why should we have a fight?
Why? We still have the cold bread.” He says, “We (have an option) without quarrel, without anything.”
Without any dispute, an issue that will not be spread out. So he says to us, “The cold bread is for us.” This is the meaning of ‘the cold bread’.
